body.name: ASUS Prime X670E-PRO WiFi Socket AM5 (LGA 1718) Ryzen 7000 ATX Motherboard(PCIe® 5.0,DDR5,4X M.2 Slots, USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C®, USB4® Support, WiFi 6E, and 2.5G Ethernet)

features: AMD AM5 socket: Ready for AMD Ryzen 7000 Series desktop processors
Enhanced power solution: 14plus2 teamed power stages, ProCool sockets, alloy chokes and durable capacitors for stable power delivery
Next-gen connectivity: PCIe 5.0, USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C, front USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type-C, USB4 header support
Made for online Gaming: Realtek 2.5 Gb Ethernet, WiFi 6E and LANGuard
Two-way AI Noise Cancelation: Reduces background noise from the microphone and audio output for crystal-clear communication in games or video conferences
Comprehensive cooling: Large VRM heatsinks, M.2 heatsinks, PCIe Slot Q-Release, M.2 Q-Latch, BIOS FlashBack, hybrid fan headers and Fan Xpert 4
Outshine RGB Aura Effect: Stylish edge lighting design, addressable RGB headers and RGB strip header support.
body.description: The ASUS Prime X670E-PRO WIFI 6E built for productivity with a robust power design, comprehensive cooling solutions and intelligent tuning options to unleash the full potential of AM4 Ryzen processors. ASUS Prime X670E-PRO WIFI 6E is perfect for those seeking to create a sleek, futuristic-looking build, thanks to its black and white finish and iridescent metallic nameplate and PCB cover.

productInformation.name: Customer Reviews
productInformation.value: 3.9 3.9 out of 5 stars 108 ratings 3.9 out of 5 stars

manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: ASUS is one of Fortune magazine’s World’s Most Admired Companies and is one of the top motherboard and gaming brands, as well as a top-three consumer notebook vendor. ASUS is driven by passion and innovation and dedicated to creating quality products for a future smart life, designing and manufacturing products that perfectly meet the needs of today's digital home, office and person. Our wide portfolio includes MG248Q, Chromebox and a range of devices and components, along with AR and VR. PRIME X670E-PRO WIFI ASUS PRIME X670E-PRO WIFI, an AMD X670E Ryzen AM5 ATX motherboard with PCIe 5.0, four M.2 slots, DDR5 slots, USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C, USB4 support, WIFI 6E, and 2.5G Ethernet AMD AM5 socket: Ready for AMD Ryzen 7000 series desktop processors Enhanced power solution: 14+2 teamed power stages, ProCool sockets, alloy chokes and durable capacitors for stable power delivery Next-gen connectivity: PCIe 5.0, USB 3.2 Gen2x2 Type-C, front USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type-C, USB4 support, WiFi 6E, Realtek 2.5 Gb Ethernet, and LANGuard Exclusive overclocking technology: AI Overclocking, Dynamic OC Switcher, and Core Flex Comprehensive cooling: Large VRM heatsinks, M.2 heatsinks, PCIe Slot Q-Release, M.2 Q-Latch, BIOS FlashBack, hybrid fan headers and Fan Xpert 4 with AI Cooling II Two-way AI Noise Cancelation: Reduces background noise from the microphone and audio output for crystal-clear communication in games or video conferences

PCIe 5.0 Slot PCIe 5.0 offers twice the data transfer speed of PCIe 4.0, making it robust enough to handle new data-heavy tasks. PCIe 5.0 also brings other benefits, such as electrical changes to improve signal integrity, backward-compatible CEM connectors for add-in cards, and compatibility with previous versions of PCI Express. Four M.2 Slots (with PCIe 5.0) Four M.2 slots support up to the 22110 device and also can provide NVMe SSD RAID for incredible performance potential. Moreover, one M.2 slot supports PCIe 5.0 with data transfer speeds of up to 128 Gbps, enabling quicker operating system boot-up and file management. *Actual transmission speeds will be lower than the theoretical maximum speed. M.2 Heatsinks Three M.2 heatsinks cover four M.2 slots, warding off throttling that can occur with M.2 storage during sustained transfers. *Removable captive screws reduce risk of drops or loss during heatsink removal.

VRM Heatsink and Thermal Pads The two VRM heatsinks on PRIME X670E-PRO WIFI are significantly larger than those found on earlier X570 motherboards. Together with the thermal pads, they improve heat transfer from the MOSFETs and chokes for better cooling performance. Robust Power Design Stable power is essential to extract every last bit of performance out of AMD processors. The PRIME X670E-PRO WIFI is geared to cater to the demands of these high-core-count CPUs. 1. ProCool Connectors Proprietary connectors augment the motherboard's link to the PSU with 8+8 pin connectors that pass 12 volts of power directly to the processors. Each jack features solid pins that can handle more current than hollow-pin connectors. 2. 14+2 Teamed Power Stages 14+2 power stages combine high-side and low-side MOSFETS and drivers into packages rated for 70 amperes each, delivering power, efficiency, stability and performance to latest AMD processors. USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C A batch of USB ports support high-end rigs loaded with peripherals, including both front and rear USB Type-C connectors with ultrafast USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 for transmission speeds of up to 20 Gbps.

WIFI 6E Onboard WiFi 6E technology takes advantage of the newly available radio spectrum in the 6 GHz band. It provides up to three times the bandwidth of the 5 GHz band and up to seven 160 MHz bands to deliver ultrafast wireless networking speeds and improved capacity as well as better performance in dense wireless environments. PCIe Slot Q-Release A physical button located on the chipset heatsink unlocks the first PCIe slot’s security latch with one press, greatly simplifying the process of detaching a PCIe card from the motherboard when it’s time to upgrade to a new GPU or other compatible device. Q-Latch The innovative Q-Latch makes it easy to install or remove an M.2 SSD without the need for specific tools. The design employs a simple locking mechanism to secure the drive and neatly eliminate traditional screws.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Update the BIOS and put the pedal to the metal
reviews.reviewText: Got this mobo a month ago (Nov'23 as of this writing.) First thing I did was update the BIOS thru the USB BIOS FlashBack method. It's pretty easy to do. If you need help, ASUS put out a video on Youtube that's only 2 minutes long .. pretty straight forward & to the point. Only thing to keep in mind with this motherboard is the boot time is rather long (about 45 seconds for mine) due to Memory Training. Since I'm new to this motherboard, I left it as is. Might tinker with it in the BIOS later on.I paired this mobo with the 7800X3D, RTX 4070, 32GB CL30 DDR5, couple of PCIE Gen 4 SSDs and a few other hard drives. When gaming, all settings are maxed out in 4K. DLSS + Frame Generation + HDR is amazingly gorgeous. Ray Tracing is turned off though. In the month since I built this system, I streamed a ton on Youtube and Twitch. I also captured lots of footage with Nvidia's Shadowplay and did quite a bit of editing with the free version of Davinci's Resolve. It's been rock solid so far!My previous setup was the legendary 4790K paired with the 1660 Super, 16GB DDR3 on the Gigabyte Z97X-Gaming 5 mobo (Yeah I know, major upgrade for me lol.) If any problems do come up, I'll be sure to update this post but so far I'm very happy with this build.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Running like a Beast with my Amd 7950x3D. No problems. Gaming on it daily 😎

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 1.0 out of 5 stars Not worth the headaches and money
reviews.reviewText: First, the SATA ports on the right side of the board will snap off with just a slight bump. They were mounted vertically, instead of sideways which led to the initial problem. So I replaced the board because losing two SATA ports meant I couldn't use my backup drives.When the replacement board came in, it wouldn't boot. ASUS doesn't put the latest BIOS on their boards. After struggling with no boot, I tried updating the BIOS. The latest BIOS has a problem with memory. Four GSkill memory sticks that worked ok on the motherboard I was replacing were not even recognized. I finally got it to boot, but with only one memory stick.I wasted a full day working with this board. I replaced it with a MSI board which took all memory sticks, and booted with absolutely no trouble. It took 5 minutes to mount the MSI board and to get to a boot screen.So I'd not recommend this ASUS board. Too much trouble, too easy to snap off SATA connectors, won't run 4 sticks of DDR5 memory.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent full feature board and incredible value from warehouse stock
reviews.reviewText: Despite some other reviews noting many issues, it seems like most of those have been worked out at this point. Running this board with a 7800x3d, 7900XTX, and DDR5 6000mhz memory and everything has been incredibly smooth. The board is beautiful, loaded with features and inputs, and especially if you can get a decent deal from the Amazon warehouse, is an unbeatable value (though not a bad find at retail). Do update the BIOS once you receive it however - I think that's where people noting problems had issues and it was the first thing I did.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 2.0 out of 5 stars Honestly pretty trash. Slow boot, random issues that require hard power off.
reviews.reviewText: What more is there to say that isn't in the header? Asus has done a piss-poor job with this board, and the stability is disgusting. Don't recommend it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great X670E motherboard.
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this motherboard a little while ago to build my new PC. I read some reviews here and they were rather mixed.I'm glad I didn't listen to the negative reviews though.If you first do a bios flash via bootable USB stick to the newest bios (only connect motherboard to PSU, no processor, ram etc. installed) it works like a charm.I've done the bios flash, then installed CPU, ram etc and installed it in my case.Works great since day 1. (Ryzen 9 7950X CPU)It performs really well and in combination with the 64gb DDR5 6000mhz G.Skill ram it's super-fast.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I don't like RGB / LEDs for visual effects on motherboards; the status lights are fine. There is a way to disable these in the BIOS and it is easy to find!I do not like that the motherboard will try to install bloatware ( Armoury Crate which is linked to performance issues in gaming, etc.. ) by default. There is an option to shut it off and I always go through the bios before installing an OS - so this ended up not affecting me, but if the bios settings reset at some point in the future without telling me then it may try to install software on my computer I do not want.It has 1 NVME x5, 2 at 4x and 1 at 3x. One of the 4x slots disables the 2 side angled sata ports - but the 2 on the bottom will work. I don't use sata connectors much anymore so I can live with 2 and with the 5x port I have room to grow.The drivers were very easy to find on their website, and I used NTLite to slipstream my Windows install - and the big thing: The NVME driver on their website actually worked. There have been a few boards in the past where it doesn't. There is also an option in the BIOS for NVME native support which is on by default. So the entire install process was hands free.Installing the OS took less than 5 minutes with all of my settings having been input into NTLite prior to plugging the USB drive in.Updating the BIOS took longer than the OS Install, which I did prior to anything. They notify you to reset the BIOS configuration PRIOR to installing - This is likely because of stability concerns which could brick your board if they don't have a backup BIOS slot, but they could do this in the background and restore settings after the install to make it more user friendly.Inexpensive board with good feature-set.-------Update: Still takes a long time to boot, but I am getting micro-stuttering in applications, games, media, etc.. Could be the CPU, could be the board. Either way this board takes way too long to boot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works Well, Looks Good, Smart Value.
reviews.reviewText: Updated the bios to the latest at the time (1813) and its been solid. It booted up on the first go. I think it crashed the first day, but since then I haven't had any issues. It has a nice look if you're going for a black/silver aesthetic. It is hefty and seems like it uses quality components. Definitely worth considering if you want a "deluxe" board with a lot of IO options for old devices (eg. sata hd's and ssd's) and newer devices (eg. pci 5.0) without going for the ROG gaming lines and don't want to spend over $500. On sale, this board is a great value.

Overall a good Motherboard for todays bloated prices.Looks great if you want a white/silver & black lookSound card is good.Issues from start: did not boot or send image to screen due to Bios (Version 0613 ) being to old, it could not see the memory for 1 hour (i was eating dinner) it normally takes a few mins to boot first time as it has to detect the memory. Went to the next bios update (Version 0809) seemed fine but had random freezing and blue screens. As I installed windows I thought maybe the memory was bad or heat.Ran mem test and tested the (Corsair Dominator Platinum RGB DDR5 32GB (2x16GB) 6000MHz C36 EXPO) memory and found a lot of memory errors. Was saddened by this as this was the first time I bought Corsair and always stuck to Kingston memory.The next day I tried the BIOS Version 0821 - and all is well I did reinstall windows again and boy it runs like a dream now.I'm running a 7600X with a Kinston M.2 gen4 2tb drive and man it is fast. even with normal boot mode.Hope it lasts as long as the other ASUS mobos. I've had and worked on. No joke, for ever... longer then you'd keep the system. Last one was 10 years and still kicking.I worked in a known PC shop and will always put ASUS above all the other brands as their failure % is way lower then ALL other brands. This is with my 13+ years as a system builder professionally .Hope this helps you guys and gals. You wont regret buying this MOBO. Its just Classy and sexy. and looks better then the ROG white one IMO.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unstable bios and fried within a day
reviews.reviewText: This MOBO has been nothing but problems. Unstable windows, bios update bricked. Had to use bios flashback, then once things were running MOBO fried and pc no longer booted. Asus RMA made me pay $90 for shipping.

Built entirely new system about a month ago, runningAsus Prime X670E-PRO WiFi, Ryzen 9 7900X, G.kill FlareX5.Flare X5 DDR5 was not listed as supported but worked greatright from the start.Great, solid board. My last Asus board is 10 years oldand still running flawlessly, which was a big decidingfactor.Looks great, running a month now without any issues,easy install, could use a few more back USB2/3 but that'sjust being picky.Good board, good price, pleased with the purchase.
The boot time was a little long at first, but now it takes like 15 secs to boot so its pretty good. Coming from Rog, i think this mobo is really near the performance of the ROGs models. I recommend.
